texts.shortText:
Mullet have cylindrical, torpedo-shaped, plain silvery bodies (usually slight depressed at the head and laterally compressed at tail end), a small terminal mouth with minute teeth, two well-separated dorsal fins and a forked tail. They form tight schools close to the surface over soft substrata. About 16 difficult-to-separate species occur in South Africa.

This species has a relatively pointed snout and a distinctive yellow spot on the operculum and is very common in the Western Cape, where it is commonly caught by beach seine fishers.

Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Angolan border to Eastern Cape.

Very tolerant of changing salinities and common from the upper reaches of estuaries to the open sea. Usually forms dense shoals over soft substrata, juveniles also commonly trapped in rock pools. A common prey species of both predatory birds and larger piscivorous fish, including sharks. An important fishery species captured in large numbers by both trek-net and gill net fisheries and commonly sold dried as bokkoms.
Early juveniles feed mostly on small planktonic crustaceans, but larger juveniles and adults eat detritus, benthic diatoms, foraminifera, filamentous algae and seagrass.
Matures at about 21 cm and in the Western Cape appears to breed close inshore throughout the year.

Can be confused with various other small silvery schooling fish such as pilchard (but these have only one dorsal fin) or maasbanker (but these have a much more slender peduncle to the tail and scute-like scales along a conspicuous lateral line). Separation from other mullet species is quite difficult and based mostly on head shape and number of scales along the lateral line (44-50 in this species). For details see Heemstra references below.
